H2A.description: H2A is of the core histones. H2A forms dimers with H2B via "hand shake" motif. Two H2A-H2B dimers in turn associate with H3-H4 tetramer to form complete nucleosome core. Structurally H2A consists of histone fold domain extended by short αC-helix and has both N- and C-terminal tails. The αC-helix and C-terminal tail form "docking domain" that locks the H2A-H2B dimer onto the surface of H3-H4 tetramer.

H2B.description: H2B is one of the core histones. H2B forms dimers with H2A via "hand shake" motif. Two H2A-H2B dimers in turn associate with H3-H4 tetramer to form complete nucleosome core. Structurally H2B consists of histone fold has long flexible N-terminal tail which protrudes between the DNA gyres. H2B interacts with H4 in nucleosome core via four helix bundle motif. Addtional αC-helix of H2B decorates the surface of nucleosome.

H3.description: H3 is one of the core histones. Two H3s and two H4s form H3-H4 tetramer via two  via "hand shake" motifs between H3 and H4 and a "four helix bundle" between two H3s. Two H2A-H2B dimers then associate with H3-H4 tetramer to form complete nucleosome core. Structurally H3 has a histone fold domain, αN-helix and a long N-terminal tail with many important post-translational modification sites. The αN-helix organizes the terminal segment of core nucleosomal DNA.

H4.description: H4 is one of the core histones. Two H4s and two H3s form H3-H4 tetramer via two  via "hand shake" motifs between H3 and H4 and a "four helix bundle" between two H3s. Two H2A-H2B dimers then associate with H3-H4 tetramer to form complete nucleosome core. H4 is the most conservatinve histone type and has least number of variants. Structurally H4 has a histone fold domain and a flexible N-terminal tail. H4 provides sites for H2B interaction via "four-helix bundle" and forms a small β-sheet with H2Aa.

H1.description: H1 is the linker histone. Associates with nucleosome core and linker DNA near the DNA entry-exit points. The resulting particle is called chromatosome. H1-histone is lysine rich, has long C-terminal tail and short N-terminal tail. The globular domain has three helices and a wing, thus termed "winged helix" motif.
